title: Feature Request: registry key for disabling saving passwords
author: bluikko
body_snippet:
mRemoteNG could have an option in registry for disabling saving passwords. This way in an enterprise setting a GPO could be deployed to disable the users from saving passwords.

I can volunteer to do the GPO-side work if this would be possible.

iterations.description: Enabling GPO/Registry-based policy to disable password saving is a standard enterprise requirement for security compliance.

comments.author: srsirius
comments.snippet:
Hi. 

On my remote server, I use a VNC 'reflector/repeater' which operates in 'Mode I' and receives my incoming VNC connection, then forwards it to a particular client's VNC server. 

The way this works is.... say my remote server is W.X.Y.Z, and the target client I want to admin is A.B.C.D With UltraVNC viewer, I specify A.B.C.D in the 'VNC Server' field (synonymous with 'Hostname/IP' in mRemoteNG), and then there is a field called 'Proxy/Repeater' in which I specify the reflector/repeater ...

comments.author: bluikko
comments.snippet:
> Hi.
> 
> On my remote server, I use a VNC 'reflector/repeater' which operates in 'Mode I' and receives my incoming VNC connection, then forwards it to a particular client's VNC server.

Did you reply to a wrong issue?

This issue has nothing to do with VNC. This issue is to request a way to disable saving passwords - for enforcing policy that users cannot save passwords.

comments.author: simonai1254
comments.snippet:
> The reason why this issue specifically mentions the registry is that it will be easy to change this setting from outside of mRemoteNG, For example with a `.reg` file or a GPO.

I get that it's easy to change a registry key, but on the other hand protecting the registry key is hard. And adding the registry key check into mRemoteNG that currently uses a file based configuration script needs some work. 
Currently I would think more of a "locked configuration" file like you can implement for Fi...

comments.author: bluikko
comments.snippet:
> but on the other hand protecting the registry key is hard.

Why would that key need to be protected? The registry key could be in a part of the registry where user has no write permissions. Or even with no controls at all, GPP is re-applied every 90 (by default) minutes.

notes:
AI triage (gemini): Enabling GPO/Registry-based policy to disable password saving is a standard enterprise requirement for security compliance.
Approach: Implement a check for a 'DisablePasswordSaving' registry key in Settings.cs; if present and true, override the save password functionality and disable the corresponding UI option.
